user_message:
An agent A claimed that the following metal_register_generic_device code violates the MISRA C 2023 rule 8.13.
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 8.13 is A pointer should point to a const-qualified type whenever possible.

</misra_rule>
<target_code>
Here is the original code of metal_register_generic_device.
```c
int metal_register_generic_device(struct metal_device *device)
{
	if (!device->name || !strlen(device->name) ||
	    device->num_regions > METAL_MAX_DEVICE_REGIONS)
		return -EINVAL;

	device->bus = &metal_generic_bus;
	metal_list_add_tail(&_metal.common.generic_device_list,
			    &device->node);
	return 0;
}
```
</target_code>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- explanation: your evaluation of the scenario provided by the agent A.
- is_report_correct: whether the report is correct or not (true/false). True means there is a violation.
</response format>
<scenario>
The agent A provided the following violation scenario:
The member device->bus has type 'struct metal_bus *' (non-const) and is assigned the address of the shared global metal_generic_bus. Since the bus object is a shared, read-only descriptor (contains function pointers and is not intended to be modified per-instance), the pointer should be to a const-qualified type (for example 'const struct metal_bus *bus' or make metal_generic_bus const) to prevent modification through the pointer.
</scenario>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are close to the target function metal_register_generic_device:
struct metal_device {
	const char             *name;       /**< Device name */
	struct metal_bus       *bus;        /**< Bus that contains device */
	unsigned int           num_regions; /**< Number of I/O regions in
						 device */
	struct metal_io_region regions[METAL_MAX_DEVICE_REGIONS]; /**< Array of
							I/O regions in device*/
	struct metal_list      node;       /**< Node on bus' list of devices */
	int                    irq_num;    /**< Number of IRQs per device */
	void                   *irq_info;  /**< IRQ ID */
}
...
struct metal_bus metal_weak metal_generic_bus = {
	.name = "generic",
	.ops  = {
		.bus_close = NULL,
		.dev_open  = metal_generic_dev_open,
		.dev_close = NULL,
		.dev_irq_ack = NULL,
		.dev_dma_map = metal_generic_dev_dma_map,
		.dev_dma_unmap = metal_generic_dev_dma_unmap,
	},
}
...
extern struct metal_state _metal
</additional code>

<instruction>
Judge whether the report is correct or not.
</instruction>
explanation: The report is correct. The member device->bus is declared as a mutable pointer (struct metal_bus *), but it is being used to point at a shared, read-only bus descriptor (metal_generic_bus) that holds operation function pointers and is not intended to be modified per-device. Under MISRA C 2023 Rule 8.13 a pointer should point to a const-qualified type whenever possible, so the API should express that intent by using a pointer-to-const (e.g. const struct metal_bus *bus) or by making the shared descriptor itself const. Note: this conclusion assumes there are no genuine writes through device->bus elsewhere in the code; if other code legitimately modifies the bus object via that pointer, then const would not be possible and there would be no violation. Given the provided snippets, using a const-qualified pointer is possible and therefore the rule is violated.
